I am not sure why we are at this maven level. @snuyanzin are you aware of the thinking behind the Maven level? \r\nI see this change targets 1.19. That does not seem appropriate. \r\nI think there is a case to review the maven levels in the pom file and put this into master and maybe version 2. I probably would not backport this change to v1 Flink as we are stabilising v1. \r\nWould the change mean that Maven version 4 would be tolerated - I am not sure whether there are breaking maven changes between v3 and 4 - it might be safer to restrict to v3.  ?

> I am not sure why we are at this maven level. @snuyanzin are you aware of the thinking behind the Maven level? I see this change targets 1.19. That does not seem appropriate. I think there is a case to review the maven levels in the pom file and put this into master and maybe version 2. I probably would not backport this change to v1 Flink as we are stabilising v1. Would the change mean that Maven version 4 would be tolerated - I am not sure whether there are breaking maven changes between v3 and 4 - it might be safer to restrict to v3. ?\r\n\r\nI am based on local packaging, but maven does not support the download of version 3.8.6 now, according to maven official documentation, versions before 3.8.8 are compatible with 3.8.8, so I think there should be a problem in this place\r\n<img width="1416" alt="æˆªå±2025-03-12 23 36 54" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/43da599b-92c1-4472-86b0-49032655c50f" />\r\n

<!--\nMeta data\n{\n  "version" : 1,\n  "metaDataEntries" : [ {\n    "hash" : "c9a11c4a3062fa34daa43bf3515105416cd109bc",\n    "status" : "SUCCESS",\n    "url" : "https://dev.azure.com/apache-flink/98463496-1af2-4620-8eab-a2ecc1a2e6fe/_build/results?buildId=66563",\n    "triggerID" : "c9a11c4a3062fa34daa43bf3515105416cd109bc",\n    "triggerType" : "PUSH"\n  } ]\n}-->\n## CI report:\n\n* c9a11c4a3062fa34daa43bf3515105416cd109bc Azure: [SUCCESS](https://dev.azure.com/apache-flink/98463496-1af2-4620-8eab-a2ecc1a2e6fe/_build/results?buildId=66563) \n\n<details>\n<summary>Bot commands</summary>\n  The @flinkbot bot supports the following commands:\n\n - `@flinkbot run azure` re-run the last Azure build\n</details>

@gaborgsomogyi I am confused about checkpoint id parameter when setting up transformation for operator. Do I have to pass current checkpointId when applying transformation? I see that default is 0\r\n\r\n```\r\npublic static <T> OneInputStateTransformation<T> bootstrapWith(DataStream<T> stream) {\r\n        return new OneInputStateTransformation<>(stream, 0L);\r\n    }\r\n```\r\n\r\nWhat are consequences if checkpointId will be different in metadata and in some operators?\r\n\r\nWhat if I want to change checkpointId, do I need to create transformatio for every operator to also update it there?

In short the provided checkpoint ID takes effect when new savepoint is created. When an existing savepoint is modified then checkpoint ID will be taken over no matter what one configures. All in all this PR is not adding ID change possibility.

So what would happen if I would provide some custom checkpoint id here:\r\n\r\n```\r\npublic static SavepointWriter newSavepoint(\r\n            StreamExecutionEnvironment executionEnvironment,\r\n            long checkpointId,\r\n            int maxParallelism) {\r\n```\r\n\r\nor here\r\n```\r\n public static <T> OneInputStateTransformation<T> bootstrapWith(\r\n            DataStream<T> stream, long checkpointId) {\r\n        return new OneInputStateTransformation<>(stream, checkpointId);\r\n    }\r\n```\r\n

For test I will go with setup like this:\r\n\r\n```\r\nvar savepointReader = SavepointReader.read(env, sourceSavepointPath);\r\nenv.setRuntimeMode(RuntimeExecutionMode.BATCH);\r\nvar savepointWriter = SavepointWriter\r\n                .fromExistingSavepoint(env, sourceSavepointPath);\r\nsavepointWriter.withOperator(uid), transformer.transform(savepointReader, env));\r\nsavepointWriter.write(targetSavepointPath)\r\n```\r\n\r\nAnd this should preserve the checkpointId right? 

Yeah, that should preserve the checkpoint ID. Any results?

@gaborgsomogyi We are still running Flink 1.20. I was managed to migrate savepoint and then read metadata that checkpoint id is retained but I am not able to start it back using Flink 1.20 due to:\r\n\r\n```\r\nCaused by: java.util.concurrent.CompletionException: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Unrecognized checkpoint version number: 6\r\n```\r\n\r\nAny chance to backporting fix to 1.20?

I could setup some job with 2.1-SNAPSHOT but I will be able to do it earliest over the weekend.

My personal opinion is that 2.x migration is not going to happen lightning fast and 1.20 has LTS support so I would backport it unless there are heavy objections. Just a side note, big tech companies are facing every issue sooner or laterðŸ™‚

@gaborgsomogyi I have found out that Kafka connector is not updated for 2.0+ version. On main branch it still uses `org.apache.flink.api.connector.sink2.StatefulSink` which got removed from 2.0+ flink-core.\r\n\r\nBecause of that I cannot test the setup of writing to Kafka. I could test migration without this, that job after migration continue from last checkpoint. Will that be enough for this PR?

I have finished a test:\r\nSetup:\r\n- checkpoints enabled\r\n- rocksdb backend\r\n- unbounded source emitting random numbers\r\n- stateful function that emits a sum\r\n- file sink\r\n\r\nTest:\r\n1. Start the job, let it run for a while\r\n2. Stop with savepoint\r\n3. Change uid of `stateful-function` to `stateful-function-tmp`\r\n4. Bootstrap `stateful-function` state using `stateful-function-tmp` as source and change value by 1000\r\n5. Validate checkpointId is preserved after migration\r\n  checkpointId is preserved\r\n7. Start job from savepoint\r\n  job continues from last checkpointId\r\n  state was updated and loaded correctly, outputs are now higher by 1000

Thanks for your efforts! The steps looks satisfying.\r\nJust to double check, is everything works on your side as expected?

Yes, there were no problem loading state and checkpointId was preserved, because of that I am confident that will help with the issue of KafkaCommitable lingering in the state. 

cc @Zakelly

> can we have a unit test?\r\n\r\nSure, I can write a test. Unrelated issue, restarted

You mean using canonical savepoint format and using various state backends? If I understand your point correctly then majority of the users are not seeking this approach. The reason is simple, with canocical format all the state data must be inserted into RocksDB one by one which results in horror execution time. The numbers are showing 3-4 times higher execution time however users are looking for quick `why my job is not working` UX. If you would like to keep it what if we can make it optional? When defined then used, otherwise Flink config value used. WDYT?

Adapted the code and rebased to the master

Merged and squashed

@snuyanzin thanks for asking. RC1 was accepted, I do not expect us incorporating changes from release-1.20 branch, so feel free to merge.

My own performance and correctness tests show the following numbers:\r\nTest data: 256Mb state file with a single operator and 2 value states\r\n- Old execution time: 25M27.126737S\r\n- New execution time: 1M19.602042S\r\n\r\nIn short: ~95% performance gain.\r\n

<!--\nMeta data\n{\n  "version" : 1,\n  "metaDataEntries" : [ {\n    "hash" : "d0d44d6196c02552179ec23c799d9769e128a8ae",\n    "status" : "SUCCESS",\n    "url" : "https://dev.azure.com/apache-flink/98463496-1af2-4620-8eab-a2ecc1a2e6fe/_build/results?buildId=65785",\n    "triggerID" : "d0d44d6196c02552179ec23c799d9769e128a8ae",\n    "triggerType" : "PUSH"\n  } ]\n}-->\n## CI report:\n\n* d0d44d6196c02552179ec23c799d9769e128a8ae Azure: [SUCCESS](https://dev.azure.com/apache-flink/98463496-1af2-4620-8eab-a2ecc1a2e6fe/_build/results?buildId=65785) \n\n<details>\n<summary>Bot commands</summary>\n  The @flinkbot bot supports the following commands:\n\n - `@flinkbot run azure` re-run the last Azure build\n</details>

I think there are different concerns here: (a) data integrity and (b) data semantics.\r\n\r\n(a) The value of a field should always return its correct value. That\

My intuitive understanding of the mentioned problem in Iceberg is why not fix the nullability of the field?\r\n`RowData` as the basic structure of flink sql, follows the semantics of sql nullability, one field declared not-null should not be filled with null values. On the other hand, if a nullable field has set null bit, then its value can be seen as null directly and no need to read the value in the memorysegment (because it is reused as much as possible at the sql runtime implementation, which can save some operations).\r\nAccurate nullability is important to the sql system, not only to ensure proper processing on the consumer side (e.g., the field may be used as the primary key of the target table, which requires not null), but also gives the planner more optimization possibilities (e.g., predicate derivation, and also the runtime code can skip the null check overhead for non-null fields, etc.).

> For the 1st part, my question is since the nullability info provided by users are not reliable, why not enforce the use of nullable type when use `RowData#createFieldGetter`? Am I missing something here?\r\n\r\nI understand where you are coming from, but not all Iceberg writers have the concept of "non-null" / required columns. A schema may have certain type definitions, but ultimately the writer decides what can be written.

I was looking to see when we decided that Gelly is no longer supported so should not be tested; I could not see anything in the Jira as to the history behind this.

> I was looking to see when we decided that Gelly is no longer supported so should not be tested; I could not see anything in the Jira as to the history behind this.\r\n\r\nDecisions like this one to delete something, in this case Gelly, per https://flink.apache.org/how-to-contribute/contribute-code/#consensus should be discussed on the Dev mailing list.\r\n\r\nSee https://lists.apache.org/thread/kfwq87t5b79ndknndhodz6o8b0d8y41v for the discussion thread and https://lists.apache.org/thread/ng5t85t1lnmzrld4vvlk0mglq3fcgj50 for the result of the vote thread

From the discussion in the Jira it seems like this change was for Python datastream. I think introducing a Python raw format to Python would be more consistent with the way Java implements this. WDYT @MartijnVisser .\r\n\r\nnaming nit: SimpleStringSchema is one String, I would read SimpleByteSchema as one byte, I suggested calling it ByteArraySchema.  

Reviewed by Chi on 30/01/2025 Go back to the submitter with review comments.

@davidradl is the consensus to rename the class from SimpleByteSchema to ByteArraySchema?

\n\n<details>\n<summary>Bot commands</summary>\n  The @flinkbot bot supports the following commands:\n\n - `@flinkbot run azure` re-run the last Azure build\n</details>

@pnowojski IIUC, the async state operator currently processes watermarks **only** after all prior async state requests have been completed. That means when the event time timer is triggered, all preceding async state access operations have already been processed. Please correct me if there is any mistake @Zakelly .

@pnowojski Glad to see you here. @xuyangzhong is right, you have that guarantee. The same-key records and timers will happen in order of arrival. That is, when watermark advance, the timer will fire after all arrived records for that key finishes. And any records for that key arrive after the watermark advance will start processing after the timer finishes. 

Thanks for your answers @Zakelly and @xuyangzhong!\r\n\r\nOne more thing. At the moment I have only sync implementation of the append-only deduplicate operator. I guess there is no harm if this is merged as is, so that the synchronous version will be used despite `isAsyncStateEnabled()` being enabled, right? The code will remain correct? And I can provide async version in a separate PR/ticket? (relevant code is in the `StreamExecDeduplicate`).

@pnowojski I believe youâ€™re correct.\r\n\r\n1. I think the current implementation of StreamCommonSubGraphBasedOptimizer has a flaw in how it handles the removal of mini-batch configs. The rank/dedup node is generated during optimization via specific patterns involving project and filter nodes. Upon further reflection, it might be more effective to remove unnecessary mini-batch assigner nodes only after the exec graph is fully generated.\r\n\r\n2. Regarding the second point: if different key configs are used during compiling plan and execute plan, it can indeed lead to issues. This applies not only to configs related to mini-batch, but also to any changes in configs marked in `ExecNodeMetadata#consumedOptions`. It would be advisable for users to recompile the plan in such cases.\r\n\r\nTo avoid blocking this PR, my suggestion is to make a slight improvement to `FlinkRexUtil#shouldSkipMiniBatch` to identify projects that include the `rank_number` function, allowing to temporarily bypass the issue. We can then create a separate jira to address this problem more thoroughly at a later time.

BTW, the ci seems failing during compiling

@flinkbot run azure

@flinkbot run azure

Thanks for the reviews. Everything is finally green. Sorry for the delay, but I had to deal with some other things in the mean time.

@flinkbot run azure

<!--\nMeta data\n{\n  "version" : 1,\n  "metaDataEntries" : [ {\n    "hash" : "3bea726773d9f287495b1eef7bdc0080b9203155",\n    "status" : "FAILURE",\n    "url" : "https://dev.azure.com/apache-flink/98463496-1af2-4620-8eab-a2ecc1a2e6fe/_build/results?buildId=65571",\n    "triggerID" : "3bea726773d9f287495b1eef7bdc0080b9203155",\n    "triggerType" : "PUSH"\n  } ]\n}-->\n## CI report:\n\n* 3bea726773d9f287495b1eef7bdc0080b9203155 Azure: [FAILURE](https://dev.azure.com/apache-flink/98463496-1af2-4620-8eab-a2ecc1a2e6fe/_build/results?buildId=65571) \n\n<details>\n<summary>Bot commands</summary>\n  The @flinkbot bot supports the following commands:\n\n - `@flinkbot run azure` re-run the last Azure build\n</details>

@asardaes I agree with @ferenc-csaky . People who are running in such memory-constrained scenarios are welcome to investigate the details of Netty configuration. The documentation section is there primarily to indicate what is the reason for the change in behavior inside of Flink. The  path for a "normal" Flink user would be to simply allocate slightly more overall memory to TMs/JM.

In my experience with Netty outside of Flink, running with the default (`io.netty.maxDirectMemory = -1`) means that the value of `-XX:MaxDirectMemorySize` will *not* be respected by Netty, so I think `taskmanager.memory.framework.off-heap.size` will no longer account for everything.

@flinkbot run azure

Reviewed by Chi on 23/01/2025 Go back to the submitter with review comments.

> why do we need a new function when we can already do this with json_object? Or am I missing something?\r\n\r\n@davidradl In many cases, JSON is generated by external systems and already exists in columns or nested fields. Many times this JSON needs to be wrapped into another JSON, for this the JSON_OBJECT function needs to know that a parameter is pre-formatted JSON. For this the SQL standard introduces a JSON data type and `JSON()` function:\r\nsee T802 [here](https://peter.eisentraut.org/blog/2023/04/04/sql-2023-is-finished-here-is-whats-new)

@twalthr thanks for your reply. It makes sense what you say - I found the code /docs associated with the pr a bit misleading - is that all the examples could be coded with a nested json_object using a key. It would be good to document when this would be useful - i.e. with external systems. I assume maybe a dynamic table with a JDBC connector and column defined as a String could use this function to convert the string to json - prior to us having the json type.  

Thanks for the reviews, @twalthr

@flinkbot run azure

Hey @ferenc-csaky , thanks for addressing this. \r\nI actually already went ahead and merged the fix for this test that was made on master after the Netty 4 upgrade.\r\nhttps://github.com/apache/flink/pull/26041\r\nhttps://github.com/apache/flink/pull/26042\r\n\r\nDo you think there are benefits to use `unpooled` config here instead? 

I think the `unpooled` will affect other places of Flink 

After I rethink it again, it should probably be not enabled here, because the test should verify the `flink-runtime` shuffle memory allocation, which was on Netty4 back in 2019 as well when it was originally implemented, so it used the `pooled` allocator since ever.\r\n\r\nEnabling reflection only seemed to stabilize the test on my machine, but since this test was flaky on the CI failed sporadically, and on my machine consistently, it may not add much. My concern about the backported commit from `master` is that it gives 90MB memory instead of 7. It states `one chunk (4M * 20) plus some margins`, which might be true for `master` if there were some other changes how we (did not follow this up), but definitely not true for 1.19 and 1.20, so IMO it invalidates this test case.

@ferenc-csaky thanks for the clarification. It sounds like the correct way would be to find out what is the off-heap overhead induced by Netty 4 default settings in RPC and bump that setting by exactly that amount. 

@ferenc-csaky could you rerun the tests without reflection and unpooled, but with a slightly increased off-heap memory? We probably need to just find the sweet spot to account for the increased off-heap memory consumption caused by the RPC.

I would like to see anyone run a test with pekko 1.2.0 nightly ... I think then @pjfanning should be happy to get that pr in

> @ferenc-csaky could you rerun the tests without reflection and unpooled, but with a slightly increased off-heap memory? We probably need to just find the sweet spot to account for the increased off-heap memory consumption caused by the RPC.\r\n\r\n@afedulov  Yeah, I cover that today.

@afedulov So on my M4 Pro chip MacBook the test starts to run with 11MB consistentlt, and consistently fail with anything under that, since TMs cannot even start because there are not enough resource to allocate for Netty. Since the CI runs on x86 machines, and only fail once in a while, it makes me think CPU architecture matters here and it allocates less memory on a non-ARM architecture. All in all this points me to think we should get away with 12MB for these tests for 1.19 and 1.20.\r\n\r\nIn the meantime I also thought a bit about where that `90mb` memory the backported commit added, and I think they just multiplied the 4M chunk by the task slot number and added some extra margin: `4m x 20 + 10 = 90m`, which is semantically wrong.

@ferenc-csaky  Cool  But the pekko 1.2.x snapshot should be binary compatible with 1.1.x\r\n\r\nAnd there are nightly on https://repository.apache.org/content/groups/snapshots/org/apache/pekko/pekko-actor_2.13/1.2.0-M0+55-a75bc7a7-SNAPSHOT/\r\n\r\nHope that saves you some time.

> @ferenc-csaky Cool But the pekko 1.2.x snapshot should be binary compatible with 1.1.x\r\n> \r\n> And there are nightly on https://repository.apache.org/content/groups/snapshots/org/apache/pekko/pekko-actor_2.13/1.2.0-M0+55-a75bc7a7-SNAPSHOT/\r\n> \r\n> Hope that saves you some time.\r\n\r\nTBH I have very limited Scala knowledge, but Flink does not support 2.13 at all, so my preconception was that I need a 2.12 build. I pretty much figured out building it from the nightly GH workflow and just finished building with this cmd:\r\n```sh\r\nsbt -Dpekko.build.scalaVersion=2.12.x "++ 2.12.x ;publishLocal;publishM2"\r\n```\r\n(After 1 failure because of `graphviz` missing...)\r\n\r\nAnd I built 1.1.x after I applied your commit from https://github.com/apache/pekko/pull/1709.

I knew , after alibaba acquired,  then more Java, thanks for that information. \n\n

@He-Pin now that it is confirmed that the "unpooled" config solves the issue for us, how realistic do you think it is to get a Pekko release with the allocator config support included soon?\r\n\r\n@ferenc-csaky I would prefer not to postpone much longer unless we get the Pekko release ASAP. Please drop a line in response to @pjfanning\

Would you like to comment on the pr against 1.1.x too.

> @He-Pin now that it is confirmed that the "unpooled" config solves the issue for us, how realistic do you think it is to get a Pekko release with the allocator config support included soon?\r\n> \r\n> @ferenc-csaky I would prefer not to postpone much longer unless we get the Pekko release ASAP. Please drop a line in response to @pjfanning\

Hi @tomncooper , it seems the link cannot be shown as expected. Could it be tested in a test repo first?\r\n\r\nhttps://github.com/apache/flink/pull/3672#issuecomment-2589741128\r\n\r\n![QQ_1736905968281](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/7177155e-4437-4c25-b75a-74851595dfc1)\r\n

Hi @1996fanrui, yes, I saw that. I copied the action from the Apache Kafka version and I think the inclusion of the html `<p>` tags is what is doing it. It is treating the the text in between as raw html. \r\n\r\nThe Kafka messages have the same issue ([example](https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/17494#issuecomment-2586118225)). \r\n\r\nFrom looking at the action docs/code it should just pass the markdown straight to GH so if we remove the tags it should work.

I see in HiveDynamicTableFactory that there are references to RequireCatalogLock

> I see in HiveDynamicTableFactory that there are references to RequireCatalogLock\r\n\r\nThe hive module has been externalized, we should focus on the code in this repository: https://github.com/apache/flink-connector-hive, the hive module in flink repository will be deleted, and now it has been removed from the pom file and no longer compiles and runs ci.

> I just checked the external Hive connector and that refers to the class we are removing. I think we need a plan for the Hive connector before removing it from core Flink\r\n\r\nWe can remove the related code when we bump flink version to 2.0 in hive connector.

I have raised https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FLINK-37097 to track the removal of the Hive connector from core flink, 

> I have raised https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FLINK-37097 to track the removal of the Hive connector from core flink,\r\n\r\nGood job, assign to you.

@flinkbot run azure

Test failures are unrelated to the change.\r\n

In general agree it is supported for most of the cases\r\n\r\nhowever there are some corner cases where it is not supported for instance in both FLOAT and DOUBLE there are `NaN`, `Infinity`, `-Infinity`.\r\nNot sure whether it is possible to make a query with `NaN` however it is possible to have something returning either `-Infinity` or `Infinity`\r\nfor instance\r\n```sql\r\nSELECT power(0, -1);\r\n```\r\nor\r\n```sql\r\nSELECT -power(0, -1);\r\n```\r\n\r\nas a result casting of these doubles will NOT work since there are now infinities in DECIMAL\r\nso it will just fail\r\n```sql\r\nSELECT CAST(power(0, -1) AS DECIMAL);\r\n```\r\n\r\nas an option we could mark it as supported \\+ add some reference note about corner cases\r\n\r\nWDYT?

Just to clarify - this PR is solely about casting to BOOLEAN. All of the below expressions work:\r\n```sql\r\n-- Casting NaN as BOOLEAN\r\nSELECT CAST(SQRT(-1) AS BOOLEAN) as nan_to_boolean;\r\n-> TRUE\r\n\r\n-- Casting Infinity, -Inifinity as BOOLEAN\r\nSELECT CAST(power(0, -1)AS BOOLEAN) as infinity_to_boolean,\r\n       CAST(-power(0, -1)AS BOOLEAN) as neg_infinity_to_boolean;\r\n-> TRUE, TRUE\r\n```

btw the failure seems to be fixed at https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FLINK-37006\r\n\r\ni think rebase should help

@snuyanzin thanks for the heads up.\r\n\r\nCould you please also stamp these two backports:\r\nhttps://github.com/apache/flink/pull/25940\r\nhttps://github.com/apache/flink/pull/25939\r\n

>I think we should consider the situation when utcTs < 0, utcTs < 0 stand for the time before 1970s.\r\n\r\nsure

@snuyanzin can we change the method in TimestampData\r\n```\r\n    private TimestampData(long millisecond, int nanoOfMillisecond) {\r\n        Preconditions.checkArgument(nanoOfMillisecond >= 0 && nanoOfMillisecond <= 999_999);\r\n        this.millisecond = millisecond;\r\n        this.nanoOfMillisecond = nanoOfMillisecond;\r\n    }\r\n```\r\nand make Preconditions.checkArgument(nanoOfMillisecond >= 0 && nanoOfMillisecond <= 999_999) to Preconditions.checkArgument(nanoOfMillisecond >= 0 && nanoOfMillisecond <= 1_000_00);

`TimestampData` is annotated with `@PublicEvolving`\r\nhttps://github.com/apache/flink/blob/4efbc9138782f07ee35c71456759187e613617b6/flink-table/flink-table-common/src/main/java/org/apache/flink/table/data/TimestampData.java#L40-L41\r\nwhich usually means there should be an approved FLIP before such a change.\r\n\r\nHowever I wonder what is the reason to change it? Why can not we fix this issue without such change?

@kurtostfeld I see your motivation for doing this, but you mention that there will not be binary compatibility with v1 state. Do you have an idea on how v1 Kyro state would migrate to v2 state after this fix? We are trying to encourage v2 migration - and this could be a big inhibitor.\r\n

@davidradl great question. That is best answered by the project leaders + managers.

Reviewed by Chi on 09/01/2025 Go back to the submitter with review comments.

> @kurtostfeld I see your motivation for doing this, but you mention that there will not be binary compatibility with v1 state. Do you have an idea on how v1 Kyro state would migrate to v2 state after this fix? We are trying to encourage v2 migration - and this could be a big inhibitor.\r\n\r\n@davidradl Sharing this info in case it helps answer your question. @kurtostfeld can correct me if I mistate anything. The original Pull Request, which was documented in this [FLIP-317](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/FLINK/FLIP-317%3A+Upgrade+Kryo+from+2.24.0+to+5.5.0) provided code to migrate older state forward. But there was some email discussion about keeping the Kryo upgrade for Flink 2.x. Because of this, there was another merge request created that was simpler and did not include the backwards compatibility. I think either Pull Request could work, but we just need someone to decide and approve before things get too stale. This [Jira ticket](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FLINK-3154) has more discussion in the comments. Also this [email discussion](https://lists.apache.org/thread/vyov944och394lql76zb3myf2g140fdw).

The Pekko folks could not reproduce this leak outside of Flink, so it is ultimately up us to help localize the issue as we cannot expect the fix to come from the Pekko side alone:\r\nhttps://github.com/apache/pekko/issues/1634\r\n\r\n@ferenc-csaky could you investigate a bit according to the advice we received?\r\nhttps://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FLINK-36510?focusedCommentId=17908999&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#comment-17908999

@ferenc-csaky just saw your comment on the symmetric 1.20 revert [PR](https://github.com/apache/flink/pull/25866), glad to see you are on it :) 

try `-Dio.netty.tryReflectionSetAccessible=true` to make it work smooth on Java 9+\r\nwith `-Dio.netty.allocator.type=unpooled` to make it keep the old unpooled behavior.

Opened https://github.com/apache/flink/pull/25956 which I believe should supersede this current PR.

@ferenc-csaky can we close this PR?

Closing this PR as it is superseded by [FLINK-37100](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FLINK-37100)

<!--\nMeta data\n{\n  "version" : 1,\n  "metaDataEntries" : [ {\n    "hash" : "e7d2bb20dc7edb78d91202359e7278ebdec7b117",\n    "status" : "SUCCESS",\n    "url" : "https://dev.azure.com/apache-flink/98463496-1af2-4620-8eab-a2ecc1a2e6fe/_build/results?buildId=64713",\n    "triggerID" : "e7d2bb20dc7edb78d91202359e7278ebdec7b117",\n    "triggerType" : "PUSH"\n  } ]\n}-->\n## CI report:\n\n* e7d2bb20dc7edb78d91202359e7278ebdec7b117 Azure: [SUCCESS](https://dev.azure.com/apache-flink/98463496-1af2-4620-8eab-a2ecc1a2e6fe/_build/results?buildId=64713) \n\n<details>\n<summary>Bot commands</summary>\n  The @flinkbot bot supports the following commands:\n\n - `@flinkbot run azure` re-run the last Azure build\n</details>

@XComp So it is better to turn on `-Dio.netty.leakDetection.level=PARANOID` to see who holds the buffers.\r\nand turn on `-Dio.netty.allocator.type=unpooled` too, then all ByteBuf lives in memory.\r\n\r\n@normanmaurer is there any suggestion, thanks.

another optimization in https://github.com/apache/pekko/pull/1667

@XComp Is there any update can share, thanks.

It would be nice if anyone could add :\r\n`-Dio.netty.tryReflectionSetAccessible=true`\r\n`-Dio.netty.leakDetection.level=PARANOID` \r\n`-Dio.netty.allocator.type=unpooled` \r\n\r\nto run tests.

@ferenc-csaky @He-Pin @XComp It looks like this PR is all about reverting the level of the pekko until we understand the cause of the OOM. All the comments seem to relate to resolving the OOM. Can I suggest we merge this revert, and investigate the OOM separately as suggested in the Jira.  

@davidradl Is there any investigation result update from your side, thanks.

Opened https://github.com/apache/flink/pull/25955 which I believe should supersede this current PR.

@ferenc-csaky sounds good - can we close this PR?\r\n

IMO yes, I will close both this one and the [1.19 equivalent](https://github.com/apache/flink/pull/25867) on Monday if no objections until then.

I believe that since we are not dealing with a memory leak but rather with different memory allocation (thanks @ferenc-csaky for confirming this!), we should aim to include the upgrade in both the 1.19 and 1.20 releases. While there is some risk of exposing users to OOM kills by pushing some workloads over hard memory limits, we have to weigh them against the risks posed by leaving numerous critical CVEs exposed on the network stack.\r\n<img width="398" alt="image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/be65d248-f7ce-4747-bb93-9f096e77bc8c" />\r\n\r\nNetty 3.10.6 is the last 3.x release and therefore officially reached EOL more than 8 years ago. I also read reports of it suffering from multiple GC and memory management issues, so it is not like we are transitioning away from something that is rock solid and works perfectly to an experimental release. \r\n\r\nThe approach proposed by @He-Pin in the above [comment](https://github.com/apache/flink/pull/25866#issuecomment-2580904462) sounds reasonable to me. If we adopt this approach, I think we should actually add `-Dio.netty.tryReflectionSetAccessible=true` parameter as default to the startup scripts, not merely to the documentation. An open question remains: should we retain the 3.x-style memory management by using `unpooled` allocations? My current understanding is that using both parameters should approximate the existing behavior, but it does not seem like `unpooled` allocation is strictly required for our case. @He-Pin, whatâ€™s your perspective on this?\r\n\r\nAs for fixing it in 1.20.2 or 1.20.1 - I am not convinced that having CI running more times will provide us required confidence. The primary concern lies in breaching memory limits in existing deployments rather than stability. If we agree this change is necessary for a patch release eventually, it would be logical to apply it now for both 1.19.2 and 1.20.1. I will make sure this potential concern is explicitly mentioned in the release notes.\r\n\r\n@ferenc-csaky Do we have a rough understanding of how much more memory consumption does this new version induce? Does it look like some fixed amount or something that scales with the number of connections? 

BTW, if Flink is supporting JDK 17+ too, please add  below when running on JDK 17 or higher\r\n\r\n```\r\n--add-opens java.base/java.nio=ALL-UNNAMED\r\n--add-opens java.base/jdk.internal.misc=ALL-UNNAMED\r\n```\r\ntoo.

@davidradl I think making the old behavior(unpooled) configurable can be done, but that will need @pjfanning to confirm backporting.\r\n\r\nAnd the change is how the PooledByteBufAllocator works, which will cache some arenas, but TBH, 7M is very small for anywork load.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n

@XComp @ferenc-csaky @davidradl @afedulov I just prepared a PR https://github.com/apache/pekko/pull/1707 for this, not sure if @pjfanning agree with backporting this to 1.1.4 release.\r\n\r\n

+1 for keeping the newer Pekko and Netty 4 in 1.20.1 (and not merging this PR). This is the LTS and my 2c is that having a more secure base and fixing any issues that arise is the better path.

A backport is pending https://github.com/apache/pekko/pull/1709 as @afedulov requested.

Thanks @Shawnsuun for adding pluggable storage backend and a new RocksDB storage backend support. This is a great addition.\r\n\r\nAt scale, we also see the current set of issues with the file/directory based storage backend for the HistoryServer especially with respect to the quick exhaustion of inodes. \r\n\r\nFlink OSS has a formal process called FLIP - Flink Improvement proposals where any new designs are vetted by the community and goes for a voting process. See [FLIP improvement proposals wiki](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/Flink/Flink+Improvement+Proposals) to know more.\r\n\r\nI am happy to help with reviewing this code. Thanks again!

> Thanks for the PR! In general I have a question: why serializing the key/value by sampling, instead of read the serialization result/length of current put/add, especially for RocksDB? WDYT @masteryhx\r\n\r\n@Zakelly In my opinion, serializing the key/value by sampling has the following reasons:\r\n1. Unlike state access latency, the size of key/value cannot be simply obtained in the outer MetricsTrackingState. For example, in RocksDBValueState#value valueBytes.length can only be accessed within the method\r\n2. Serializing the key/value by sampling can also collect statistics on other types of statebackend, not only for RocksDB\r\n

@Zakelly @masteryhx kindly remind

@flinkbot run azure

@Zakelly @masteryhx  Could you please take a look when you have time?

> Thanks, @yuchen-ecnu, for your contribution. I ran a WordCount job locally and tested the new web UI. I found that the checkbox `Show Pending Operators (Remaining: 0)` is always displayed regardless of whether there are any pending operators. I prefer not to display it if there are no pending operators. WDYT?\r\n> \r\n> 1. @snuyanzin Yes, because this ticket just handle the SECOND and MINUTE case.

the root cause is same, if you compare output for different inputs, it will be same.\r\nThe jira issue was raised for the case the reporter faced however it does not mean it is limited only for this input\r\n

At least we have to support it for all timeunits for which we have already existing tests \r\nfor instance if there is a test for `MILLISECOND` like here https://github.com/apache/flink/blob/72b32fcd53f2d0d81329298a6c0a7d08e084f769/flink-table/flink-table-planner/src/test/java/org/apache/flink/table/planner/functions/TimeFunctionsITCase.java#L449-L458\r\nthen same should be supported for case with cast as well.\r\n\r\nIf there is no such for `NANOSECOND` then we could skip it\r\n\r\n\r\n

Is it possible that `@wbmnky/license-report-generator` includes transitive dependencies, while `licence-report` does only direct?\r\n\r\nDoes any of the tools also include copies of the actual licenses used?\r\nAs you can see here: https://github.com/apache/flink/blob/master/flink-runtime-web/src/main/resources/META-INF/NOTICE we are including the license texts in the file as well, because basically all OS licenses require to ship a copy of the license as well.

Reviewed by Chi on 21/11/24. Asked submitter questions. \r\n\r\n

@flinkbot run azure

@ammu20-dev could you squash the commits please.

Since we need to finalize 1.19.2 and 1.20.1 releases and the consensus is that introducing such critical classpath changes is too risky, I am going to push out the fix versions in Jira to 1.19.3 and 1.20.2 for now (in case some of the folks who worked on the larger job submission [rework](https://github.com/apache/flink/pull/25472) would be willing to help out here). \r\n@ammu20-dev thanks for you efforts, I am sorry that we could not merge your PR.

> But while debugging the issue I found that the class loader coming here is the App class loader and not the user class loader.\r\n\r\nIn that case the primary question should be - why does the `userClassLoader` class field not contain the actual user class loader in the first place. Should not that be the focus of the fix instead of pulling it out of the resourceManager only for one the methods?\r\n\r\n> and I see minimum possibility on regressions.\r\n\r\nUnfortunately, I can\

> In that case the primary question should be - why does the `userClassLoader` class field not contain the actual user class loader in the first place. Should not that be the focus of the fix instead of pulling it out of the resourceManager only for one the methods?\r\n> \r\n\r\n@afedulov That sounds reasonable. I will investigate more on this and try to figure out the reason. Meanwhile do you think a more targeted fix would be a better approach here. Something that is confined to [StreamingJobGraphGenerator.prevalidate](https://github.com/apache/flink/blob/4b306699811af0b6ff2cb862914adfda56345996/flink-streaming-java/src/main/java/org/apache/flink/streaming/api/graph/StreamingJobGraphGenerator.java#L502) method level by removing the class loading happening [here](https://github.com/apache/flink/blob/4b306699811af0b6ff2cb862914adfda56345996/flink-streaming-java/src/main/java/org/apache/flink/streaming/api/graph/StreamingJobGraphGenerator.java#L535). Due to this issue, the ADD JAR statement is causing a job failure when checkpointing is enabled, which is preventing to use this feature in production. \r\n\r\n

Here is the summary on the outcomes from the PR review:\r\n\r\n1. Externally added jars are resolved using the FlinkUserCodeClassLoader(child classloader) in flink. This fix involved updating the class loader at the graph execution level with the user code class loader which is expected as per naming convention of the variable [here](https://github.com/apache/flink/blob/a4563caa7a4914dfd9fa5d488f5b2e541ecc582a/flink-streaming-java/src/main/java/org/apache/flink/streaming/api/environment/StreamExecutionEnvironment.java#L2472) in the source code.\r\n2. However, the issue is already fixed in a safe tested way in Flink 2.0 as part of this [PR](https://github.com/apache/flink/pull/25472). If this issue exists for several Flink versions (from 1.16) then we should not introduce large and risky changes in a patch version to fix it. \r\n3. Since the issue has existed since version 1.16 (over 2 years) and is only relevant for the Table API the risk is not worth it(see [comment](https://github.com/apache/flink/pull/25656#issuecomment-2582320914)). So we can conclude that ADD JAR capability with Table API  will be a known limitation till version 20 and the same can be used with Flink 2.0.\r\n\r\nBased on the above findings I am closing this PR.

>Reviewed by Chi on 05/12/24 Approve - looking for committer to merge\r\n\r\n@davidradl please do not confuse people with such comments\r\nas mentioned above there is still one comment expecting a tiny change before merging\r\nhttps://github.com/apache/flink/pull/25646#discussion_r1863831314\r\n\r\nUPD: I would consider a good approach to have an agreement on approval between participating reviewers before making decision that a committer is required for merging

> > Reviewed by Chi on 05/12/24 Approve - looking for committer to merge\r\n> \r\n> @davidradl please do not confuse people with such comments as mentioned above there is still one comment expecting a tiny change before merging [#25646 (comment)](https://github.com/apache/flink/pull/25646#discussion_r1863831314)\r\n> \r\n> UPD: I would consider a good approach to have an agreement on approval between participating reviewers before making decision that a committer is required for merging\r\n\r\n@snuyanzin thanks for the feedback. I see how this could be misleading. I guess PRs could have \r\n1- no reviewers \r\n2- some reviewers\r\n3- some reviewers with a committer involved - like this one. \r\n\r\nSo if there is an active committer moving the PR through - then this comment could be misleading as it implies something additional is needed, but everything is progressing. Maybe we just say `business as usual `or `in hand`, in this case; just to show we have looked at it. \r\n\r\nMaybe we have another comment. `Needs review approvals` for the 2nd case.\r\nAnd `needs committer review / merge`, if the reviewers have all approved. \r\n\r\nAm I understanding your concern correctly? WDYT?\r\n

@davidradl not sure that this is the right place to discuss it here...\r\nI have nothing against your comments in general.\r\n\r\nMy point is: if there is already a comment requesting some changes \r\nthen all the other comments after that one with "approve" without referring to the requesting changes \r\nmight lead to wrong understanding that everything is approved and losing that requesting change comment...\r\nI guess same is happening here and now since in general this discussion has nothing to do with the PR\r\nso may be you can have a special wiki page accumulating such feedback/comments\r\n

@snuyanzin I agree that this is not the right place for discussion. Maybe add a comment to [https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/FLINK/Community+Health+Initiative+(CHI)+workgroup](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/FLINK/Community+Health+Initiative+(CHI)+workgroup) and/or we could use the dev list for the discussion so everyone can be involved.

can we see \r\n```\r\n./mvnw dependency:tree | grep json-path\r\n```\r\noutput to be sure it is fixed?

@snuyanzin This PR only fixes the direct dependency on `json-path` used by `flink-table-runtime`. There is a transitive dependency on `json-path` 2.7.0 that comes from Calcite 1.32 which is used by the `flink-table-calcite-bridge`. That is dealt with for master by #25602 and backported for 1.20 in #25613.

I agree the PR description could be clearer. I can either update that or combine all the upgrades?

I would prefer combining upgrades in one since we are going to do this to solve a pretty clear issue

@snuyanzin I have merged the PRs for `json-path` and CI has passed.

thanks, i think we are close to merge it\r\ni have one last comment

Thanks @snuyanzin, I think we are good to go.

Nice quick optimisation, thanks!

> Nice quick optimisation, thanks!\r\n\r\nI am very happy to be able to make something that will help flink!

I think this would be pretty useful, just wondering about if we enable it by default could it break something in any CI? My understanding is that by default the index file is placed into the project root, and I think that would break the RAT license checker. But even if not, or if we add an exception for the index in the RAT config doing this extra step in CI runs has no much value, as that always runs start a clean slate, cloning the code, etc.\r\n\r\nAll in all, I think disabling this by default would be a safer choice, we can introduce a property for it to make it easy to enable indexing via a dynamic param in any local run. WDYT?

@flinkbot run azure

@jnh5y @ruanwenjun Thanks for the added thoughts! I am okay with updating this PR with simply bumping the spotless version to `2.35.0` instead of what is happening currently in a different commit and force push the PR branch. Putting the index file under `target/` is not harmful at all, so my original point does not matter anyway.\r\n\r\n@ruanwenjun Would you mind adapting the Jira ticket ticket summary/desc and the PR title accordingly as well?

<!--\nMeta data\n{\n  "version" : 1,\n  "metaDataEntries" : [ {\n    "hash" : "4f453b0b3d724daf8640de5388d5f448969d051d",\n    "status" : "SUCCESS",\n    "url" : "https://dev.azure.com/apache-flink/98463496-1af2-4620-8eab-a2ecc1a2e6fe/_build/results?buildId=63022",\n    "triggerID" : "4f453b0b3d724daf8640de5388d5f448969d051d",\n    "triggerType" : "PUSH"\n  } ]\n}-->\n## CI report:\n\n* 4f453b0b3d724daf8640de5388d5f448969d051d Azure: [SUCCESS](https://dev.azure.com/apache-flink/98463496-1af2-4620-8eab-a2ecc1a2e6fe/_build/results?buildId=63022) \n\n<details>\n<summary>Bot commands</summary>\n  The @flinkbot bot supports the following commands:\n\n - `@flinkbot run azure` re-run the last Azure build\n</details>

cc @Zakelly @dmvk 

I have reproduced this issue easily, but I could not reproduce it if snapshot compression is turned on. \r\n\r\nIIUC when using snapshot compression, `SnappyFramedInputStream#available()` will return the number of bytes uncompressed in the buffer, and we should skip those.\r\n\r\nWhen not using snapshot compression, we call `BufferedInputStream#available()` which will be the number of buffered bytes, and in my tests the buffer size was 4096, so if we read e.g. 50 bytes of data during the last deserialization, this was 4046. \r\nSkipping this many bytes resulted in the next seek having to seek backwards, and that will cause the S3 client to close and re-open the stream.\r\n\r\nCould you reproduce this issue with state compression enabled?

Doing backports to all branches where this issues exists.

Since the hintOptions required for these tests are stored in a map \r\n\r\nin fact we use embedded jackson functionality which sorts properties in abc order in case of maps

Thanks for the reveiw.\r\n\r\n>I have a small question: Why are the OpenContext interfaces empty, while the DefaultOpenContext and WithConfigurationOpenContext are quite simple? Could these simple OpenContext subclass be combined into one?\r\n\r\nThis is by design: We want to use different implementations to distinguish different cases (passing different combinations of arguments to `Open`) to avoid incompatible changes to interfaces/classes.\r\n\r\nBTW, I have rebased the master and resolved conflict.

Thanks for the reveiw!
